F060hr4x.title: Influence of inlet flow rate, pH, and beads mill operating condition on separation performance of sub-micron particles by electrical hydrocyclone
F060hr4x.abstract: Experimental studies have been carried out about the separation performance of a special electrical hydrocyclone. In this study, effect of inlet flow rate, applied electrostatic potential, pH, and beads mill operating condition on separation performance of a special electrical hydrocyclone were investigated. A 0.5 wt% suspension of sub-micron silica dispersed by the beads mill was used as the test powder. A 20 mm electrical hydrocyclone in diameter with 20% of underflow was examined. A negative center electrode was vertically inserted inside the conical section and the potential difference up to 100 V was applied between the conical wall and the center electrode in the hydrocyclone. By use of beads mill, it was found that the negative values of zeta potential increases with the increase of the particles diameter. It was found that the separation performance of the electrical hydrocyclone increases significantly with the decrease of inlet flow rate and increase of the electrostatic potential, while the separation performance shows a less significant increase as the pH of suspension increases. Under several times of milling by use of the same beads, the values of zeta potential were not constant. The negative zeta potential of suspension attains the highest value under six times of milling by use of the same beads. A new model, based on the diffusive mass transfer equation in the conical section of the electrical hydrocyclone has been developed, and compared to the experimental results. It is found that the calculated results by the new model shows a qualitative agreement with the experimental results. Keywords Hydrocyclone Electrostatic enhance Beads mill Sub-micron silica Particle separation Nomenclature B d underflow ratio (–) C suspension concentration (g/cm 3 ) D diffusivity (cm 2 /s) D p 50 50% cut size diameter D ¯ p mass median diameter (μm) D p particle diameter (μm) E strength of the electrostatic field (V/cm) f centrifugal rotor rotational speed (rpm) f c Δ D p , f f Δ D p particle size distributions of coarse and fine sides, respectively (–) k Boltzmann’s constant m c , m f mass of collected particles for coarse and fine sides, respectively (g) n number of beads used (–) Q, Q ∗ volumetric inlet flow rate, average inlet flow flow rate in the conical section, respectively (cm 3 /s) R, z , θ radial, axial and tangential direction coordinate, respectively (cm) R, R i average radius of the conical wall, radius of the center electrode, respectively (cm) t mill , t wait milling time and waiting time, respectively (min) T absolute temperature (K) v r , v z , v θ radial, axial and tangential velocity of particle, respectively (cm/s) z height of the conical section of hydrocyclone (cm) Greek letters Δ η , Δ η E , Δ η D combined partial separation efficiency, partial separation efficiency due to diffusion and due to electrophoretic, respectively (–) Δ V potential difference (V) μ fluid viscosity (g/m.s) σ surface charge density (C/cm 2 ) ρ p , ρ f particle and fluid density, respectively (kg/m 3 ) ζ zeta potential (mV) 1 Introduction Hydrocyclone separator has been widely used as the solid–liquid classification apparatus because of simple in construction, requires low operating and maintenance cost and can be used under the wide range of operating conditions [1,2] . Currently the recent interest about hydrocyclone separator is to separate the particles in the sub-micron region with a fairly high degree of classification, since the particles with such size range (0.1–1 μm) are required for various powder handling processes. Iinoya et al. [3] found that it was possible to classify powders of sub-micron size range by use of a special gas cyclone. Many improvements of the gas cyclone configuration have been continuously developed to obtain the smaller cut size. Several methods of flow controlling method at the outlet pipe of the hydrocyclone were reported [4,5] , and some new methods of controlling the cut size of the hydrocyclone by modifying the inlet section have been developed [6,7] . Estimations for 50% cut size for hydrocyclones have been obtained via various approaches [8–11] . The use of additional applied potential by considering the electrophoretic properties of the particles in order to enhance the separation performance of gas cyclones without increasing their pressure drop has been examined, and the effect of various operating conditions and dimensions on the separation performance of electrically enhanced gas cyclones have been reported [12–14] . Several models predicting the separation performance of electrically enhanced gas cyclone have been built [15,16] . Compared to that of the electrical gas cyclones, fewer studies have been carried out about the effect of applied external electrostatic potential on the separation performance in the hydrocyclone. Since the dimensions of most hydrocyclones are smaller compared to gas cyclones, and the dielectric constants of liquids are much larger compared to those of gases, smaller applied electrostatic potential, which leads to less energy consumption, can be applied in order to obtain the classification of fine particles. The first work about electrical hydrocyclones has been reported by Yoshida et al. [17] . A semi-empirical correlation based on the experimental data predicting the 50% cut size of a special electrical hydrocyclone has been developed by Pratarn et al. [18] . In this work, our goal is to optimize the hydrocyclone and decrease the cut size until it reaches the sub-micron region. The minimum cut size achieved by use of the typical laboratory scale hydrocyclone is about 5 μm under normal operating conditions and 3 μm under high pressure conditions. By use of t he multiple inlets, the cut size could be reduced until about 2 μm [19] . However, the typical hydrocyclone which depends only on the tangential force is unable to separate the sub-micron particles. In order to separate the sub-micron particles, the additional force should be applied in the apparatus. Our previous study indicates that by use of a special electrical hydrocyclone under low flow rates, the achieved cut size was about 0.4 μm [20] . This paper describes the effect of suspension flow rate, applied electrostatic potential, pH and the beads mill operating conditions on the separation performance of the sub-micron particles by the special electrical hydrocyclone. A new model based on the diffusive mass transfer mechanism in the conical section is proposed in order to estimate the separation performance of the special electrical hydrocyclone. 2 Experimental methods The experimental apparatus of the electrical hydrocyclone is shown in Fig. 1 . The system in general, consists of a hydrocyclone with a 20% underflow ratio and a suspension mixing tank. Well-dispersed 0.5 wt% of silica suspension was pumped into the hydrocyclone with low flow rates, since only the effect of the electrostatic force on the separation performance of the special electrical hydrocyclone, not the inertial force, was considered as the main driving force of separation in the hydrocyclone. A 0.1 M NaOH solution was used to control the pH of the suspension. The temperature of the feed suspension was controlled to 30 °C, and the discharged flows of both overflow and underflow were returned to the slurry tank. The experiments were carried out within 20 min in order to maintain steady conditions. The samples of both fine and coarse suspensions were collected, and the mass of each sample was measured. The Dynamic Light Scattering method (HORIBA Co. Ltd., LB-550) was used as the particle size distribution analyzer, and the zeta potential of the suspension was measured by a zeta size measuring device (Zetasizer 2000 by Malvern Instrument Co. Ltd.). The partial separation efficiency, Δ η , was calculated by: (1) Δ η = m c f c Δ D p m c f c Δ D p + m f f f Δ D p In the above equation, m c and m f represent the masses of the dried collected particles, while f c Δ D p and f f Δ D p are the particle size distributions of coarse and fine sides, respectively. A 20 mm diameter hydrocyclone was employed in this study, a center rod was inserted vertically inside the conical part, and the test section was electrically insulated from both the circular inlet and underflow box sections. Since the silica particles in the suspension are negatively charged inside an electrostatic field, in order to achieve separation by use of electrostatic force, the center rod should be controlled as the negative electrode and the conical wall as the positive one. Both the center electrode and the wall of the conical section were connected to a DC power generator. The generated electrostatic field caused by the potential difference between the wall of conical section and center electrode enables the movement of negatively charged silica particles toward the wall of the conical section, as shown in Fig. 2 . Sub-micron silica particles with 0.2 μm in median diameter and specific surface area of 22.7 m 2 /g was used as the test powder. The true density of the particles is 2.2 g/cm 3 , and their size distribution is shown in Fig. 3 . A beads mill (UAM-015 by Kotobuki Industries Co. Ltd.) was used as the method of particle dispersing before the separation experiment by the electrical hydrocyclone. Beads milling method was selected because it is effective in dispersing the sub-micron particles, and can increase the zeta potential of the particles. Under dispersing by the ultrasonic disperser device, it was found that the absolute zeta potential value was lower and the values were independent on particle diameter. The schematic representation of the beads mill apparatus is illustrated in Fig. 4 . The milling apparatus vessel contains a rotor, rotating at 2970 rpm, and 150 μm spherical silica beads in the lower side. The sub-micron silica particles suspended in the ion exchanged water were supplied into the vessel under a closed loop system. In the milling vessel, the agglomerated fine particles were forcefully broken into their well-dispersed primary size by the beads. The beads and the remaining agglomerated particles were removed from the suspension in the upper part of vessel by centrifugal force. The well-dispersed suspension was then recycled back into the suspension tank. The milling process was carried out within 30 min. After the process was finished, the suspension was kept in a calm condition for about 90 min, before the separation experiment was carried out. In the electrical hydrocyclone experiment, several experimental conditions were investigated as follows: 1. Effect of inlet flow rate ( Q = 1.2–0.1 l/min). 2. Effect of applied electro-potential (Δ V = 60–100 V). 3. Effect of pH (pH 6.5–8.5). 4. Effect of the beads mill operating condition, in this paper, the effect of the number of the beads used ( n = 1–8) on the separation performance of electrical hydrocyclone. 3 Experimental results and discussion 3.1 Relationship between the particle diameter and zeta potential The relationship between the median particle diameter and zeta potential is shown in Fig. 5 . The data shown in Fig. 5 was obtained by use of the forced centrifugal separator, under the different rotational speeds of 10,000–15,000 rpm. Larger particles are subjected to a greater negative charging, compared to the smaller ones, when the electrostatic potential is applied. Increase of the particle diameter means the increase of the interfacial area between suspended particles and the bulk liquid. Higher interfacial area implies a larger number of the ions attached at the surface of the particles. Consequently, the larger particles have greater electrical mobility compared to the smaller ones in an electrostatic field. In the electrical hydrocyclone, the larger particles might be collected at the positive electrode (the conical wall) and then move down through the lower outlet orifice. The drag force from the liquid would exceed the electrostatic force of smaller particles, and they would move through the upper outlet orifice. Hence, the separation of the particles in the electrical hydrocyclone can be achieved only by use of electrostatic force. 3.2 Effect of inlet flow rate on separation performance of electrical hydrocyclone In order to examine the effect of inlet flow rate on the separation performance of electrical hydrocyclone, the experiments were carried out under the flow rate of 1.2, 0.5 and 0.1 ℓ/min, respectively. Under such low flow rates, it is very difficult to separate the sub-micron particles without the enhancement of electrostatic force in the hydrocyclone. The applied electrostatic potential was 100 V and the suspension with normal pH (pH 6.5) was used. The influence of suspension flow rate on partial separation efficiency in electrical hydrocyclone is shown in Fig. 6 . The separation performance of electrical hydrocyclone increases with the decrease of inlet flow rate. This phenomenon contrasts with the typical hydrocyclone, in which the separation performance increases significantly as the flow rate increases. The 50% cut size corresponding to the volumetric flow rate conditions of 1.2, 0.5 and 0.1 ℓ/min conditions were about 0.49, 0.4 and 0.29 μm, respectively. The same trend has been obtained by Lim et al. [12] , by use of an electrically enhanced gas cyclone. The lower inlet velocity of the suspension means longer residence time of the particles in the electrical hydrocyclone, and results in a better particle separation. Fig. 6 also shows that with decreased inlet flow rate, the 100% cut size is shifted to a smaller region of particle diameter. Under the flow rate of 1.2, 0.5 and 0.1 ℓ/min, the 100% cut size were about 0.53, 0.45 and 0.41 μm, respectively. In the experiment, it was found that the separation of particles in the electrical hydrocyclone was not taking place under the suspension flow rate greater than 1.2 ℓ/min. Under such regions of flow rates, large particles have insufficient charge to be separated by the electrostatic force, while the centrifugal force of the particle is inadequate to enable the classification of the sub-micron silica particles. 3.3 Effect of applied electro-potential on the separation performance of the electrical hydrocyclone In order to examine the effect of electrostatic potential on the separation performance of the electrical hydrocyclone, the experiments under various electrostatic potential conditions, ranging from 60 to 100 V, were carried out. The suspension with normal pH was used in the experiment. Fig. 7 describes the effect of electrostatic potential on the separation performance of the electrical hydrocyclone. The figure shows that better separation performance is obtained under the higher applied potential, and the 100% cut size is shifted to the smaller region of particle diameter under the applied potential of 100 V, compared to conditions of 60 and 80 V. The 50% cut size are 0.37, 0.35 and 0.30 μm under the case of applied potential of 60, 80 and 100 V, respectively. The strength of electrostatic field between the center wire and the conical wall increases with the rising of the applied electrostatic potential. The increase of the electrostatic field causes the increase of the particles’ radial migration velocity, and the particles are easier to move towards the conical wall and be captured there. Hence, the higher partial separation efficiency values are obtained under the higher applied potential. 3.4 Effect of pH on separation performance of electrical hydrocyclone Since the test sub-micron silica particles are negatively charged, the negative zeta potential value of the suspension increases with the increase of the suspension pH. The zeta potential value represents the potential difference between the bulk liquid and the second layer of surrounding ions (Stern layer) near the particles. The zeta potential indirectly describes the degree of the charging state of the particles. The OH − ions released by the addition of NaOH solution into the suspension behave as additional support and increase the electrophoretic movement of particles, and subsequently increase their radial migration velocity in the electrical hydrocyclone. Fig. 8 describes the relationship between the pH of suspension and its zeta potential. In the experiment, a 0.1 M NaOH solution was used to control the pH. The negative zeta potential values increased from −42 mV under pH equal to 6.5 to about −60 mV under pH equal to 8.5. In order to investigate the effect of pH on the separation performance of the electrical hydrocyclone, the experiments were conducted under the suspension pH of 6.5, 7.5 and 8.5, respectively. Fig. 9 indicates the effect of pH on the partial separation efficiency of electrical hydrocyclone. The separation performance increases slightly with the increase of pH, and the 100% cut size is not shifted to the smaller region of particle diameter as the pH increases. The 50% cut size diameter, D p 50 , are 0.48, 0.47 and 0.42 μm under the pH of 6.5, 7.5 and 8.5, respectively. There are two phenomena regarding the mobility of the particles under different pH. First, the particle charging increases with the increase of pH, resulting in an increase of the particles’ migration velocity. Second, the current increases significantly under a constant applied potential, and the potential gradient of bulk liquid between the center rod and conical section decreases. Decrease of the potential gradient causes the decrease of the particles’ mobility. It is thought that the second phenomenon is the more dominant factor that affects the migration velocity of the particles, as the pH increases. And as the final result, the gradient of particles’ mobility decreases with the increase of pH. The partial separation efficiency shows no great improvement by increasing the pH of suspension, and the difference between the separation performances is decrease under the higher pH regions. Kobayashi et al. [21] also found that even the surface potential of silica particles increases, the gradient of particles’ mobility decreases with the increase of the pH, and becomes zero under the pH of greater than 9. Under those conditions the mobility of the particles is constant. On the other hand, the electrostatic current exhibits an extremely high value (above 150 mA) at pH 9.5. This condition is dangerous and possesses a serious risk for the apparatus. Therefore it is not recommended to classify the sub-micron silica particles in a suspension having the pH of more than 9.5 by use of an electrical hydrocyclone. 3.5 Effect of the beads mill operating condition on the separation performance of electrical hydrocyclone In this study, the number of beads used was selected as the beads mill operating conditions. The effect of the other milling condition, that is the waiting time of suspension after milling have been described in our previous report [20] . It was found that the zeta potential of the suspension is not constant after being dispersed several times by use of the same beads. Fig. 10 shows the relationship between the zeta potential of the suspension and the number of beads used. In the figure, t mill means the milling time and t wait is the waiting time, that is the calm condition time between end of dispersion by beads mill and the starting of separation by use of electrical hydrocyclone. The negative value of zeta potential increases when the beads are used from 1 to 6 times ( n = 1–6). The negative values then decrease until n = 12, and reached relatively constant value for n is greater than 12. The SEM images of the feed particles after being dispersed by the same beads for several instances of milling are shown in Fig. 11 . At n = 2, some silica particles in the suspension were found broken, while at n = 6, the silica particles indicated good spherical shape. At n = 8, the contamination of the beads was found in the suspension. It is considered that the surface charge of the particles indicates the optimum value under the perfect spherical shape of the surface, while the appearance of the beads contaminants in the suspension reduces the charging level of the particles. With the beads contaminants presence in the suspension, some of silica particles tends to stick on the surface of the contaminants and agglomerate there, as shown in Fig. 11 ( n = 8). The interfacial areas between the suspended particles and the bulk liquid decreases, and leads to the decrease of particle surface charge and the zeta potential of the suspension. Fig. 12 describes the effect of the number of beads used on the partial separation efficiency of electrical hydrocyclone. The figure shows that the separation of the sub-micron silica particles in the electrical hydrocyclone exhibits the best performance under the highest negative value of zeta potential, that is under the n = 6 condition, compared to that of under n = 2 and n = 8 conditions. The D p 50 for n = 2, 6 and 8 are about 3.9, 3.2 and 3.8 μm, respectively. It can be concluded, on the basis of our experiment, that the zeta potential of the suspension plays the most significant role in the separation of sub-micron particles by the use of the electrical hydrocyclone. Increasing the negative value of zeta potential without increasing the pH of suspension could improve the separation performance of the electrical hydrocyclone. Furthermore, the amount of broken particles and beads contamination after dispersed in the beads mill should be minimized in the next future study. Use of smaller beads in the beads mill apparatus, or lowering the rotational speed of the centrifugal rotor aiming to create the better circular shape of the particles are the recommended methods in order to improve the dispersion of the sub-micron silica suspension. 4 Proposed model In order to predict the partial separation efficiency of the electrical hydrocyclone accounting for both the particle deposition by the electrical force and diffusion phenomenon, a radially coordinated mass transfer equation in the conical section of the electrical hydrocyclone is applied, since the particle classification due to the electrostatic force takes place in this section. A mass transfer equation without tangential terms is developed, since the tangential velocity is considered negligible in this study. The equation is written as follows: (2) ν r ∂ C ∂ r + ν z ∂ C ∂ z = D r ∂ ∂ r r ∂ C ∂ r The radial and axial velocities are obtained by the following equations: (3) ν r = D p σ 10 7 ( - Δ V ) 3 μ r ln ( R / R i ) and (4) ν z = Q ∗ π R 2 - R i 2 Substituting Eqs. (3) and (4) into Eq. (2) : (5) D p σ 10 7 ( - Δ V ) 3 μ r ln ( R / R i ) ∂ C ∂ R + Q ∗ π R 2 - R i 2 ∂ C ∂ Z = D r ∂ ∂ r r ∂ c ∂ r Since Eq. (5) is too difficult to be solved analytically, the terms in the left hand of Eq. (5) are solved separately. By use the following boundary conditions: (6) C = 0 at R and R i The detailed derivation of the partial separation efficiency equation is written in Appendix . The partial separation efficiency due to electrostatic force can be written as follows: (7) Δ η E = 1 - exp - K 1 D p σ ( - Δ V ) Q ∗ + B d where (8) K 1 = 4 x 10 7 π Z 3 μ ln ( R / R i ) The partial separation efficiency due to diffusion is: (9) Δ η D = 1 - exp - K 2 D Q where (10) K 2 = 8 π Z ( R i 2 + R 2 ) ( R i 2 - R 2 ) + 1 ln ( R i / R ) D is the diffusion coefficient. In the calculation, the Brownian diffusion is considered to be taking place, since the flow within the conical section is thought to be laminar: (11) D = kT 3 π μ D p To combine the partial separation efficiency of both mechanisms, the following equation is used: (12) Δ η = Δ η e + ( 1 - Δ η e ) Δ η D The combined equation of partial separation efficiency of both the electrostatic and diffusion mechanisms is as follows: (13) Δ η = 1 - exp - K 1 D p σ ( - Δ V ) + K 2 D Q + B d exp - K 2 D Q In Eq. (13) , the only unknown parameter is the surface charge density, σ . The value of σ can be found by fitting the calculated results to the experimental data, with the value of σ as the fitting parameter. By fitting, it can be concluded that the value is about −3.89 × 10 −6 C/cm 2 . Fig. 13a shows the comparison between the experimental and calculated results of the effect of inlet flow rate, while Fig. 13b shows the case of the effect of applied electrostatic potential on the partial separation efficiency of the electrical hydrocyclone. The predictions of partial separation efficiency are on the qualitative agreement with the experimental data. 5 Conclusions Experimental studies about the separation performance of the special electrical hydrocyclone have been conducted, and a model based on the mass transfer phenomenon in the conical section has been built in order to predict the partial separation efficiency of the electrical hydrocyclone. The obtained conclusions are as follows: (i) The negative zeta potential of the sub-micron silica particles increases with the increase of the particle diameter, hence the classification by use of applied electrostatic potential in the hydrocyclone was possible. (ii) The partial separation efficiency of the electrical hydrocyclone increases with the decrease of the inlet flow rate. (iii) The partial separation efficiency of the electrical hydrocyclone increases with the increase of the applied electrostatic potential. (iv) The partial separation efficiency of the electrical hydrocyclone slightly increases with the increase of the pH values of the suspension. (v) The zeta potential of the solution is not constant after being dispersed several times by the use of the same beads mill. It is found that particles which dispersed under the condition of being milled six times have the best circular shape and the lowest zeta potential. Under that milling condition, the best separation performance of the special electrical hydrocyclone was achieved. (vi) The estimation of the new model based on the mass transfer mechanism which accounts for the partial separation efficiency due to the electrostatic force and diffusion is qualitatively in agreement with the experimental results. Appendix The derivation of the model based on the diffusive mass transfer equation in order to calculate the partial separation efficiency is explained in this section. Fig. 14 describes the assumption made in the model development. The fluid flow and particles axial movement and flow splitting in the real condition of hydrocyclone is described in Fig. 14 a. The fluid flow and the flow splitting is simplified as shown in Fig. 14 b in order to build a simpler model, since only the underflow ratio is considered has a significant effect in particle deposition in case of electrical hydrocyclone. The average radius of conical section is used in the model development. Fig. 14 c shows the particle deposition mechanism due to the electrical force in the electrostatic field inside the conical section of hydrocyclone. The radial velocity of particles in the conical section of electrical hydrocyclone, due to the electrostatic force is as follows: (A1) ν r = D p σ 10 7 E r 3 μ (A2) E r = - Δ V r ln ( R / R i ) Therefore, Eq. cvvIUNH5.title: Automatic measurement of vertical cup-to-disc ratio on retinal fundus images
cvvIUNH5.abstract: Glaucoma is a leading cause of permanent blindness. Retinal fundus image examination is useful for early detection of glaucoma. In order to evaluate the presence of glaucoma, the ophthalmologist may determine the cup and disc areas and diagnose glaucoma using a vertical cup-to-disc ratio. However, determination of the cup area is very difficult, thus we propose a method to measure the cup-to-disc ratio using a vertical profile on the optic disc. The edge of optic disc was then detected by use of a canny edge detection filter. The profile was then obtained around the center of the optic disc in the vertical direction. Subsequently, the edge of the cup area on the vertical profile was determined by thresholding technique. Lastly, the vertical cup-to-disc ratio was calculated. Using seventy nine images, including twenty five glaucoma images, the sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 85% were achieved with this method.

vfE8xfbk.title: Cross-talk between signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 and estrogen receptor signaling.
vfE8xfbk.abstract: Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a multifunctional cytokine that plays important roles in the immune system, hematopoiesis, and acute phase reactions. Estrogens have significant roles in a variety of biological events, such as the development and maintenance of female reproductive organs, and bone and lipid metabolism. Previous studies demonstrated that estrogens suppress IL-6-induced osteoporosis and the growth of multiple myeloma cells by repressing IL-6 and IL-6 receptor gene expression. Here we present a novel mechanism for the inhibitory effect of estrogens on IL-6 function. IL-6-induced activation of signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) activity and STAT3-mediated gene expression were suppressed by 17beta-estradiol (E2) in breast cancer cells. E2-mediated inhibition of STAT3 activation was reversed by tamoxifen, an estrogen receptor (ER) antagonist. We provide evidence that the inhibitory action of ER on STAT3 activity was due to direct physical interactions between STAT3 and ER which represents a novel form of cross-talk between STAT3 and ER signaling pathways.
keywords: signal transducer and activator of transcription 3
signal transducer and activator of transcription

iOW6HvJF.title: Effect of multi-inlet flow on particle classification performance of hydro-cyclones
iOW6HvJF.abstract: The effect of multi-inlet flow on particle classification performance of hydro-cyclones was examined experimentally and via a simulation study. Cut size of the type A cyclone with two inlets flow indicated smaller cut size and sharp separation performance compared to the standard cyclone. The type B cyclone with a small additional flow injection area, showed smaller cut sizes as the flow rate of the additional flow increased. The type B cyclone showed smaller cut size compared to the standard cyclone.

LNpNp5P4.title: Intraocular pressure-lowering efficacy of latanoprost in patients with normal-tension glaucoma or primary open-angle glaucoma.
LNpNp5P4.abstract: We investigated the intraocular pressure (IOP)-lowering potential of latanoprost in patients with normal-tension glaucoma (NTG) or primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). This prospective study included 59 NTG and 20 POAG patients treated with the following four dosing regimens of latanoprost: patients on no previous medication received latanoprost as initial therapy (Group 1, n=31), patients on beta-blocker therapy received latanoprost as adjunctive therapy (Group II, n=9), patients on unoprostone monotherapy were switched to latanoprost monotherapy (Group III, n=14), and patients previously on dual therapy with isopropyl unoprostone and beta-blocker were switched to a combined treatment of latanoprost and beta-blocker (Group IV, n=25). IOP significantly decreased 8 weeks after initiation of latanoprost therapy by 19.9% in Group I, 20.5% in Group II, 16.6% in Group III, and 12.2% in Group IV. In Groups I and II, there was a significant positive correlation between the magnitude of IOP reduction induced by latanoprost and the IOP level before latanoprost therapy. The IOP level before latanoprost therapy is a contributing factor in the IOP-lowering efficacy of latanoprost. Latanoprost is more effective in lowering IOP than isopropyl unoprostone.
LNpNp5P4.venue: Journal of ocular pharmacology and therapeutics : the official journal of the Association for Ocular Pharmacology and Therapeutics

5sjtAtUb.title: Domain observation and molecular orientation of chiral dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine monolayer by Brewster angle microscopy and Maxwell displacement current
5sjtAtUb.abstract: To understand the relationship between molecular chirality and electrical properties of monolayers, Maxwell displacement current (MDC) behaviors and domain shapes of chiral DPPC monolayers composed of dextro- ( d -) and levo- ( l -) rotatory molecules at the air–water interface are investigated during monolayer compression using MDC measurement and the Brewster angle microscopy (BAM) system. The experimental results show that for DPPC monolayers of the two pure enantiomers, the π-A isotherms and the MDC behaviors are similar to each other, while the domain patterns of them are mirror shapes of different sizes. This reveals that MDC behaviors due to molecular spontaneous polarization have no relation to chirality but domain shapes closely depend on the molecular chirality. Moreover, the observed domain shapes verify the domain shape theory which was recently developed by Iwamoto et al. [M. Iwamoto, Z.C. Ou-Yang, Phy. Rev. Letts, 93 (2004) 206101].

BuOfQS6q.title: Myocilin Gly252Arg mutation and glaucoma of intermediate severity in Caucasian individuals.
BuOfQS6q.abstract: To determine the phenotype of an Australian pedigree with the myocilin (MYOC) Gly252Arg mutation, comparing it with other pedigrees carrying the same mutation.All recruited subjects underwent a comprehensive clinical examination, including optic disc assessment, applanation tonometry, and visual field measurement. Mutation analysis was performed through direct sequencing. Haplotype analysis was performed using microsatellite markers around the MYOC gene.Eight Gly252Arg mutation carriers with glaucoma were identified from the same pedigree. Carriers' mean +/- SD age at diagnosis was 46.3 +/- 11.4 years (range, 31-60 years). Highest recorded intraocular pressure ranged from 27 to 42 mm Hg (mean +/- SD, 32.4 +/- 5.6 mm Hg). Cup-disc ratios in the worst eye ranged from 0.6 to 0.9. Six of the 8 individuals had undergone filtration surgery. A common founding haplotype between MY5 and D1S218 was found for Caucasian individuals tested with this mutation. One subject was compound heterozygotic for the MYOC Gly252Arg mutation and a novel MYOC Gly244Val variant.Although a common founder for Gly252Arg across Caucasian subjects was found, the phenotype from this Australian MYOC mutation-carrying pedigree is less severe than previously described. The severity of glaucoma caused by the Gly252Arg mutation may be similar to the Thr377Met MYOC mutation, yet is more severe than the most common Gln368Stop mutation.Since its implication in glaucoma, much work has been performed investigating the clinical features of MYOC-related glaucoma. Given the strong genotype-phenotype correlations with MYOC disease-causing variants, health care professionals armed with such molecular information are able to accurately counsel patients on their likely disease course. Our work suggests that the disease associated with MYOC Gly252Arg is less severe than previously described in other pedigrees with this specific mutation.

Dq41XR5T.title: Trabeculectomy with mitomycin C for normal-tension glaucoma.
Dq41XR5T.abstract: A prospective investigation of the postoperative intraocular pressure level, visual function changes, and postoperative complications of trabeculectomy with adjunctive mitomycin C in normal-tension glaucoma.Thirty-one patients (31 eyes) who underwent trabeculectomy with 0.4 mg/ml mitomycin C were studied. The preoperative intraocular pressure of the eyes ranged from 11 to 18 mm Hg with a mean (+/- SD) of 14.1 +/- 1.9 mm Hg. Follow-up examinations were performed at least once a month for 14-35 months (mean: 24.4 months).Intraocular pressures decreased to between 4 and 14 mm Hg with a mean (+/- SD) of 8.4 +/- 2.4 mm Hg at the last three follow-up visits. The magnitude of the intraocular pressure reduction ranged from 1 to 10 mm Hg, with a mean of 5.8 mm Hg. Final measurements of postoperative intraocular pressure ranged between 5 and 12 mm Hg in 27 eyes (87%). Visual acuity deteriorated two lines or more in seven eyes, which was caused by cataract. The visual field deteriorated postoperatively in two eyes (6%): their respective postoperative intraocular pressures averaged 9.4 and 7.5 mm Hg. Hypotonous maculopathy developed in three eyes (10%).Trabeculectomy with mitomycin C appears to have potential as a treatment modality of choice for normal-tension glaucoma, because a large majority of the patients in the present study achieved an intraocular pressure allegedly beneficial in managing normal-tension glaucoma.

y2wEDtYu.title: Phase I/IIa trial of chemoradiotherapy plus autologous formalin-fixed tumor vaccine for newly diagnosed glioblastoma: Association between complete resection and delayed-type hypersensitivity response.
y2wEDtYu.abstract: e13029 Background: We report a prospective phase I/IIa clinical trial of fractionated radiotherapy (FRT) concomitant with Temozolomide (TMZ) , followed by autologous formalin-fixed tumor vaccine (AFTV) and TMZ maintenance in patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma multiforme (GBM). Methods: Twenty-four patients (aged 16-75 years; Karnofsky performance scale score 60% or more before initiation of FRT) with newly diagnosed GBM received a total dose of 60 Gy of FRT with daily concurrent TMZ. After a 4-week interval, the patients received three AFTV injections and the first course of TMZ maintenance chemotherapy for 5 days, followed by multiple courses of TMZ for 5 days in each 28-day cycle. Results: This treatment regimen was well toleratedby all patients. The percent of patients with progression-free survival (PFS) ≥24 months was 33%. The median PFS, median overall survival (OS), and the actuarial 2-year survival rate of the 24 patients were 8.2 months, 22.2 months, and 47%, respectively. The median PFS ...

I0WweBtI.title: Transient ischemic injury in the rat retina caused by thrombotic occlusion-thrombolytic reperfusion.
I0WweBtI.abstract: To establish a clinically relevant model of transient retinal ischemia by thrombotic occlusion-thrombolytic reperfusion of the central retinal artery of the rat.Thrombus was photochemically induced in the central retinal artery by the combination of intravenous injection of photo-sensitive dye, rose bengal, and green laser irradiation focused on the artery. Transient retinal ischemia for 60 minutes was achieved by a subsequent systemic administration of tissue-type plasminogen activator to reperfuse the occluded vessel. Samples of retinas were excised from the animals killed 3, 9, 12, 24, 48, and 78 hours after the reperfusion. The experimental data were processed using the TdT-dUTP terminal nick-end labeling (TUNEL) method to detect apoptotic cells.The transient retinal ischemia caused time-sequential apoptotic changes in the retinal cells as evaluated by counting the number of TUNEL-positive cells. The most remarkable changes occurred in the central area of retina, and further on the sections taken 24 hours after reperfusion. The peripheral area was less affected, and the outer nuclear cell layer was almost unaffected throughout the observation period.The proposed method to cause retinal transient ischemia is highly reproducible, and it is easy to simulate the progress and topographical distribution of retinal changes observed in the clinical cases of central retinal arterial occlusion and its subsequent thrombolytic reperfusion. This may provide a useful tool for constructing the effective thrombolytic strategies against the central retinal arterial occlusion and for evaluating the effects of neuroprotective agents.

vEfzZ4Sm.title: Effects of substrate temperature on crystallinity and electrical properties of Ga-doped ZnO films prepared on glass substrate by ion-plating method using DC arc discharge
vEfzZ4Sm.abstract: The effects of substrate temperature, T s , on the crystallinity and the electrical properties of Ga-doped ZnO films (GZO) with a thickness of 200 nm were investigated. GZO films were prepared on glass substrates at various T s in the range from 150 to 400 °C by ion-plating method with DC arc discharge. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that GZO film prepared at 250 °C shows the preferential orientation of c -axis and the highest crystallinity. Williamson–Hall analysis indicates that the crystallite size of GZO films remains nearly constant with increasing T s up to 300 °C, and then, with further increasing T s , decreases gradually. The Ga concentration in the films, estimated by secondary ion mass spectroscopy and X-ray fluorescence analyses, increases monotonically with increasing T s above 250 °C. Hall effect measurements show that resistivity decreases slightly with increasing T s up to 250 °C, leading to the lowest resistivity of 2.1 × 10 − 4  Ω cm at 250 °C, and then exhibits a gradual increase with further increasing T s . Keywords ZnO GZO Transparent conductive film Ion plating Substrate temperature Low resistivity 1 Introduction Polycrystalline ZnO films on glass and plastic substrates have been extensively developed for many applications such as transparent electrodes, sensors, thin film transistors, and microwave shielding. In particular, low resistivity ZnO films with high visible transmittance and small surface roughness allow for the application to transparent electrodes of this material. At present, indium tin oxide (ITO) is mainly used as the electrodes in various optoelectronics devices. However, it has the problem of limited resource of its principal component, indium. Thus, ZnO films composed of low cost and abundant material are expected at the moment as an alternative to ITO electrodes in large size devices such as flat panel displays and solar cells. We have deposited Ga-doped ZnO (GZO) films on glass substrate at 200 °C by an ion-plating method with a DC arc discharge. This deposition system works very well from an industrial view point, because it enables the deposition of GZO films: 1) with low plasma damage, 2) at high rate of e.g. 170 nm/min, and 3) on large-area substrate [1,2] . In our previous works [3,4] , the effects of O 2 gas flow rate during the deposition, Ga 2 O 3 content in target source and film thickness on the electrical properties of GZO films have been investigated. Consequently, we have succeeded in obtaining a resistivity as low as 2.2 × 10 − 4  Ω cm in GZO film with a thickness of 200 nm on glass substrate at a temperature of 200 °C. The aim of this work is to investigate the effects of substrate temperature, T s , on the crystallinity and the electrical properties of GZO films. The variation in the electrical properties of GZO films with T s is investigated in terms of its crystallinity, crystallite size and Ga concentration. 2 Experimental GZO films were deposited on alkali-free glass substrate by ion-plating system with DC arc discharge using a pressure-gradient-type plasma gun [5] . In this deposition system, the substrate traveled through the deposition room for the film growth. A series of GZO films with a thickness of 200 ± 5 nm was prepared at various T s in the range from 150 to 400 °C. Deposition rate of GZO films strongly depended on T s . As will be shown in Fig. 1 , the difference in the deposition rates between GZO films prepared at T s of 150 °C and 400 °C was about 85 nm/min. Therefore, the traveling speed of the substrate was adjusted in the range of 3 to 6 mm/s to realize the same thickness of 200 nm in all GZO films. The substrate was rinsed ultrasonically in deionized water and isopropyl alcohol, and then jet-dried using high-purity nitrogen gas. A base pressure in the vacuum chamber prior to deposition was about 2.0 × 10 − 5  Pa. After evacuation of the chamber, argon and oxygen gases were introduced at the gas flow rate of 140 and 8 sccm, respectively. The deposition pressure was 2.2 × 10 − 1  Pa. A sintered ZnO ceramic target which contains a Ga 2 O 3 powder of 4 wt.% was used as a source material (99.99% purity, Hakusui Tech.). The applied DC arc discharge current between the target and the plasma gun was automatically controlled to be about 142 A. The distance from the target to the traveling substrate was fixed at about 0.6 m. Thickness of the film was measured by using a surface profilometer (Alfa-Step, IQ). Crystallinity and crystallite size of the films were characterized by high-resolution X-ray diffraction (XRD: RIGAKU, ATX-G system) analysis using CuKα radiation ( λ = 1.5406 Å). The electrical properties of the films were characterized by Hall effect measurements in the van der Pauw configuration (Accent, HL5500PC) at room temperature. Ga concentration in the films was estimated by secondary ion mass spectroscopy (SIMS) and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy analyses. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Deposition rate Fig. 1 shows the deposition rate of GZO films as a function of T s . From Fig. 1 , it is obvious that the deposition rate decreases monotonously from 200 to 115 nm/min, as the T s increased from 150 to 400 °C. For this result, we have confirmed that there is no change of deposition parameters other than T s . During the deposition, the total and O 2 partial pressure remained a constant independently of T s , respectively. The plasma conditions such as arc current, discharge voltage and target bias etc. were also the same among the samples. Thus, it is suggested that the decrease of the deposition rate is only due to the increase of the T s . The increase of the T s enhances the migration of species on the surface. This will possibly lead to the formation of more dense film. The increase of film density could effectively decrease the deposition rate. In addition, desorption from the film has been often attributed to the decrease of deposition rate with the increase of T s . We observed in a thermal desorption spectroscopy analysis that, by a post-annealing at the temperature above about 300 °C, zinc begins to desorb from the film prepared at 200 °C. Accordingly, the decrease of the deposition rate may be explained by the migration effect and the desorption of zinc. 3.2 Crystalline quality and crystallite size In order to investigate the crystallinity of GZO films prepared at different T s , out-of-plane XRD measurements were performed. Fig. 2 shows a typical XRD θ –2 θ scan profile of GZO film prepared at 250 °C. The diffraction intensity on the vertical axis in Fig. 2 is expressed in a logarithmic scale. In Fig. 2 , only two diffraction peaks from ZnO (0002) and (0004) planes were observed, where no other phases were detected. All the films prepared at different T s basically showed same diffraction pattern. This result indicates that the films are composed of a wurtzite type hexagonal structure and have a preferential orientation of c -axis normal to the substrate plane. It is well known that ZnO films consist of columnar grains grown with the c -axis orientation [6] . The full width at half maximum of the (0002) diffraction peak, FWHM θ –2 θ scan , is plotted as a function of T s in Fig. 3 . The FWHM θ –2 θ scan decreases with increasing T s from 150 to 200 °C. It seems to be a plateau in the T s range from 200 to 300 °C, and then increases gradually with further increasing T s up to 400 °C. The decrease in the FWHM θ –2 θ scan represents the improvement of the film crystallinity. Thus, these experimental findings indicate that the GZO film deposited at the T s around 250 °C has the highest crystallinity. The improvement of the crystallinity can be probably explained by the enhancement of the migration effect, as described in Section 3.1 . On the contrary, the crystallinity is deteriorated at the higher T s more than 300 °C. This is attributed to the increase of Ga concentration into the films, as will be shown in Fig. 6 . In our previous work [3] , we reported that the crystallinity of GZO films is deteriorated by the increase of the Ga concentration. Next, a crystallite size of a -axis parallel to the substrate plane was estimated from in-plane XRD data analysis on the basis of a Williamson–Hall method [7] . Fig. 4 shows the crystallite size as a function of T s . With increasing T s up to 300 °C, the crystallite size remained nearly constant at approximately 30 nm, and then, with further increasing T s , reduced to about 20 nm. Here, the crystallite size will be related to a nucleation density in the initial stage of film deposition. As described in Section 3.1 , the migration and desorption effects were argued as a factor causing the decrease of the deposition rate with increasing T s . The enhancement of the migration generally limits the density of nuclei formed in the nucleation stage, and simultaneously, this effect contributes the crystallite growth of the a -axis with the lowest surface energy plane. However, the result of Fig. 4 differs from this consideration. The desorption of zinc could be remarkable at higher temperature. The desorption may affect the nucleation stage and result in the decrease of crystallite size. A further study is necessary to reveal that. 3.3 Ga profile SIMS measurements were performed with Cs + primary ions to investigate the distribution of Ga in GZO films. The Ga concentration was quantified using the relative sensitivity factor, which was obtained by measuring the Ga-implanted ZnO reference sample. The reference sample was prepared by Ga ion implantation to an undoped-ZnO polycrystalline film, where the Ga ions are implanted at a dose of 5 × 10 14 ions/cm 2 , with an acceleration voltage of 200 keV. The error range was estimated within ± 10%. A SIMS profile of GZO film prepared at 250 °C is shown in Fig. 5 . The artificial peak located at a depth of 200 nm probably corresponds to the interface between the film and substrate, as indicated by a broken line. From Fig. 5 , the distribution of the Ga concentration was found to be nearly uniform from the surface to the interface. 3.4 Electrical properties Fig. 6 shows the resistivity, carrier concentration and Hall mobility of GZO films as a function of T s . In addition, the Ga concentration in the films, estimated by SIMS and XRF analyses, is also shown. As seen from Figs. 3 and 6 , it should be noted that the variation trend in the resistivity with T s is very similar to that of FWHM θ –2 θ scan . This suggests that the crystallinity of the films can be closely associated with the behavior of the electrical properties. In Fig. 6 , their variation trends with T s could be mainly divided into two regions; Region I up to 250 °C, where the resistivity indicates a slight decrease, and Region II above 300 °C, where the resistivity increases gradually. In Region I, the carrier concentration and the Ga concentration of GZO films are not directly affected by T s , while the Hall mobility increases, where the FWHM θ –2 θ scan decreases with increasing T s in this range. The increase of Hall mobility can be explained by the improvement of the crystallinity. As a result, at T s of 250 °C, the lowest resistivity of 2.1 × 10 − 4  Ω cm was obtained in GZO film with carrier concentration of 1.1 × 10 21  cm − 3 and Hall mobility of 27.6 cm 2 /Vs. In addition, as shown in Fig. 4 , the crystallite size remains a constant in Region I. In Region II, both the carrier concentration and Hall mobility decreased. As shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , the deterioration of the crystallinity and the reduction of the crystallite size are observed with increasing T s in this range. They correspond to the increase of scattering and trapping factors for carrier electron in the grain and grain boundary, respectively. In addition, the Ga concentration in Region II is higher than that in Region I. This will be induced by the desorption of zinc from the film, as described in Section 3.1 . Excess Ga will give rise to the segregation of Ga-oxides in the films, which acts as a donor killer. However, we have obtained no direct evidence concerning the structure of the grain boundary to date. 4 Summary The effects of substrate temperature, T s , in the range from 150 to 400 °C on the crystallinity and electrical properties of GZO films were investigated. Deposition rate of the films decreases monotonically from 200 to 115 nm/min with increasing T s . XRD analysis shows the improvement of the film crystallinity with increasing T s up to 250 °C, while, at higher T s , they are deteriorated. Williamson–Hall analysis indicates the crystallite size decrease from 30 to 20 nm with increasing T s above 300 °C. SIMS and XRF measurements reveal that Ga concentration changes a little with increasing T s up to 250 °C, while, at higher T s , an increase in Ga concentration is observed. Hall effect measurements show that the lowest resistivity of 2.1 × 10 − 4  Ω cm is obtained in GZO film at 250 °C. Acknowledgements The financial support from the collaboration of Regional Entities for the Advancement of Technological Excellence of the Japan Science and Technology Agency is gratefully acknowledged. References [1] M. Tanaka H. Makino R. Chikugo T. Sakemi K. Awai J. Vac. Soc. Jpn. 44 2001 435 [2] K. Iwata T. Sakemi A. Yamada P. Fons K. Awai T. Yamamoto M. Matsubara H. Tampo S. Niki Thin Solid Films 445 2003 274 [3] T. Yamada K. Ikeda S. Kishimoto H. Makino T. Yamamoto Surf. Coat. Technol. 201 2006 4004 [4] T. Yamada S. Kishimoto H. Makino N. Kuroiwa T. Yamamoto Proc. of 6th int. Conf. on Coatings on Glass and Plastics 2006 335 [5] J. Uramoto J. Vac. Soc. Jpn. 25 1982 660 [6] X. Jiang C.L. Jia B. Szyszka Appl. Phys. Lett. 80 2002 3090 [7] G.K. F48pTgCh.title: Tissue type plasminogen activator facilitates NMDA-receptor-mediated retinal apoptosis through an independent fibrinolytic cascade.
F48pTgCh.abstract: To investigate the association between apoptosis and the fibrinolytic system in retinal cell damage.Tissue type plasminogen activator-deficient (tPA(-/-)), urokinase type plasminogen activator-deficient (uPA(-/-)), plasminogen activator inhibitor-1-deficient (PAI-1(-/-)), alpha2 antiplasmin-deficient (alpha2 AP(-/-)) mice, and their wild-type counterparts were used. Retinal cell damage was induced by intravitreal injection of the excitotoxin N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA). The TdT-dUTP terminal nick-end labeling (TUNEL) method was used to examine retinal cell damage.tPA(-/-) mice were resistant to retinal cell damage caused by administration of NMDA, and PAI-1(-/-) mice were more injured than their wild-type. No significant difference was observed between uPA(-/-) or alpha2 AP(-/-) and their wild-type mice.The results strongly suggest that endogenous tPA, but not uPA acts as a facilitator in NMDA-induced retinal cell damage, and that its mechanism may not be associated with cleavage of plasminogen into plasmin in the fibrinolytic cascade.

Nrhij5Mb.title: Effects of the O2 flow rate and post-deposition thermal annealing on the optical absorption spectra of Ga-doped ZnO films
Nrhij5Mb.abstract: The optical absorption spectra of polycrystalline Ga-doped ZnO (GZO) thin films deposited by ion plating with direct current arc discharge have been studied. The GZO films that were deficient in oxygen showed absorption in the visible wavelength range. The intensity of the absorption band decreased with increasing O 2 flow rate during the deposition. Post-deposition thermal annealing in air and in a N 2 gas atmosphere also decreased the intensity of the absorption band. The intensity of the absorption band showed a slight correlation with carrier concentrations in the GZO films. The absorption intensity decreased with the decrease of the carrier concentration and diminished at a carrier concentration of around 7 × 10 20 cm − 3 . The contribution of carriers from native donors to transport in GZO films is discussed. Keywords ZnO Ga Transparent conductive oxide Optical absorption Optical property 1 Introduction Heavily Ga-doped ZnO (GZO) films are one of the most promising candidates for transparent electrodes in flat panel display applications [1–3] . Recently, we reported the feasibility of GZO films as practical common electrodes on color filter substrates in thin film transistor liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCD) [4,5] . In addition to their electrical properties, their optical properties are essential characteristics of transparent electrodes. Generally, the optical properties are characterized by transmission, reflection, and absorption spectra. The optical absorption spectrum is the most important because it directly influences the optical characteristics of TFT-LCD panels. In transparent conductive oxide (TCO) films, the optical absorption is related to the electrical properties of the films [6] . In the near-infrared wavelength region, free carrier absorption is the dominant contribution to optical absorption, whereas the fundamental optical band gap absorption is the main feature in the short wavelength ultraviolet region. The optical band gap could be shifted by its carrier concentration through Burstein–Moss effects [7] . In the visible wavelength region, we may observe some absorption bands due to defects or impurities, which form deep level electronic states within the band gap. Thus, the optical absorption gives some information on defects, impurities, and electronic states in TCO thin films. However, very few studies have paid attention to such optical absorption spectra in ZnO-based TCO films. We have studied the deposition of low resistivity and highly transparent polycrystalline GZO films on glass and plastic substrates by an ion plating method with direct current arc discharge [1,3] . It is well known that the electrical properties of GZO films are strongly affected by the O 2 partial pressure during deposition [8,9] . Post-deposition annealing also affects the electrical properties of GZO films [10,11] . Furthermore, the thermal stability of GZO films is poor in the case of ambient oxidation, as in an air atmosphere [12] . In both cases, oxygen will play a crucial role in altering the electrical properties of GZO films. However, the detailed mechanism of this alteration has not been fully understood. Studies on optical absorption spectra could give some insight on this point of view. In this study, we examine the changes in the optical absorption spectrum as a function of the O 2 flow rate during deposition and due to post-deposition thermal annealing for polycrystalline GZO films deposited by the ion plating method. 2 Experimental procedures GZO films, 150 nm in thickness, were deposited on alkali-free glass substrates (Corning 1737) by an ion plating method with direct current (DC) arc discharge. The details of the deposition system have been reported elsewhere [13,14] . The substrate temperature was settled at about 110 °C, which is low enough compared to the heat resistance of color filters, which are composed of organic materials. Sintered tablets of ZnO (purity 99.99%) containing 4 wt.% Ga 2 O 3 (purity 99.9%) (Hakusui Tech, SKY-Z) were used as the evaporation source. During the deposition, high purity Ar and O 2 gases were introduced into the deposition chamber. The flow rate of Ar gas was 240 sccm and that of the O 2 gas was varied from 8 to 14 sccm. The base pressure and deposition pressure were ~ 9 × 10 − 5 Pa and ~ 0.5 Pa, respectively. The discharge current was 100 A. The electrical properties of the GZO films were characterized by Hall effect measurements using the Van der Pauw method (Nanometrics, HL5500PC) at room temperature. Optical transmission and reflection measurements were carried out at room temperature in the wavelength range between 250 and 2500 nm using a grating spectrometer (Hitachi, U4100) with an angle of incidence for light of 5°. Then the optical absorption coefficient α was obtained using the formula α = 1 d ln 100 − R T , where, d is the film thickness, and R and T are the reflectance and transmittance, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The electrical properties of GZO films deposited by the ion plating method were affected by the O 2 flow rate during deposition [14] . We obtained the minimum resistivity with an O 2 flow rate of 11 sccm and a substrate temperature of about 110 °C. We selected three typical samples to study, the GZO film deposited at the optimum condition (11 sccm), the film deposited at a lower O 2 flow rate (8 sccm) and the film deposited at a higher O 2 flow rate (14 sccm). The resistivity ρ , Hall mobility μ , and carrier concentration N , determined by the Hall measurements on the GZO films are summarized in Table 1 . The actual Ga concentrations in the GZO films, which were evaluated by X-ray fluorescence analysis, are also indicated as a reference. The minimum resistivity of 2.8 × 10 − 4 Ω cm was obtained at the O 2 flow rate of 11 sccm. The carrier concentration monotonously decreased as the O 2 flow rate increased. However, the Hall mobility rapidly increased up to the optimal point with increasing O 2 flow rate. Then it saturated or only slightly increased beyond the optimum condition. Note that the Ga concentration was regarded as nearly the same, independent of the O 2 flow rate within the present range. Accordingly, the decrease in carrier concentration with increasing O 2 flow rate is predominantly caused by the O 2 gas, which assists in the oxidation of the films. The decrease in carrier concentration can be tentatively attributed to effects of some intrinsic defects. The average transmittance in the visible wavelength region was more than 85% for all samples. However, we found some changes in the optical absorption spectra depending on the O 2 flow rate. The optical absorption spectra of the as-deposited GZO films are shown in Fig. 1 . Free carrier absorption and fundamental optical gap absorption are observed as the main contributions in the near-infrared wavelength region and in the ultraviolet region, respectively. These features are typical characteristics of optical absorption spectra in TCO films. Weak tail absorption below the optical gap absorption was extended to around 400 nm. It can be seen that the intensity of the free carrier absorption decreased as the O 2 flow rate increased. On the other hand, the fundamental optical gap absorption shifted to a long wavelength as the O 2 flow rate increased. These observations are consistent with a change of carrier concentration. In addition, we found that an absorption band in the visible wavelength range between 400 and 600 nm clearly appeared in the films deposited with an 8-sccm O 2 flow rate. To see the change in the absorption in the visible range more clearly, we subtracted the tail of the free carrier absorption, assuming a relationship between α and wavelength λ , α ∝ λ p [15] , for the short wavelength region. The absorption spectra after the subtraction are plotted as a function of photon energy in Fig. 2 . We can see that the intensity of the absorption band between 2 eV and 3 eV decreased with increasing O 2 flow rate, and the absorption nearly diminished at the O 2 flow rate of 14 sccm. The optical absorption in this energy region can be attributed to some intrinsic defects in the GZO films. The absorption band observed below the band gap in undoped ZnO has been as ascribed to oxygen vacancies acting as native donors in ZnO [16,17] . Although the origin of the absorption band observed in the GZO films with the O 2 -deficient deposition condition is not clear, the decrease in the intensity of the absorption band suggests a decrease in the density of some defects in the GZO films as the O 2 flow rate increased during the deposition. This is consistent with a previous Raman scattering study [18] . In the Raman measurements of GZO films [18] , a Raman mode that was ascribed to oxygen vacancies decreased as the O 2 flow rate increased during the deposition of GZO films by the ion plating method. The influence of post-deposition thermal annealing on the electrical properties of GZO films deposited by the ion plating method has already been reported for the optimized O 2 flow rate [9,11] . In this study, we examined the GZO films deposited at the slightly O 2 -deficient condition of 8 sccm, which results in the prominent optical absorption in the visible wavelength range, to determine the effects of post-deposition annealing on the absorption band. The GZO films deposited at 8 sccm were annealed for 30 min both in air and in a pure N 2 gas atmosphere at the temperatures between 200 and 450 °C. The electrical properties were strongly affected by the post-deposition annealing. Fig. 3 shows the resistivity ρ , Hall mobility μ , and carrier concentration N of GZO films after post-deposition thermal annealing as a function of the annealing temperature T anneal . The resistivity was either stable or slightly decreased up to 300 °C in air and up to 400 °C in the N 2 gas atmosphere as T anneal increased. Then the resistivity began to increase beyond these critical temperatures. As shown in Fig. 3 (b) and (c), the Hall mobility increased and the carrier concentration decreased as T anneal increased up to the critical temperatures. Beyond the critical temperatures, both the Hall mobility and carrier concentration abruptly decreased. These observations are similar to the case of GZO films deposited at the optimal O 2 flow rate of 11 sccm [12] . The increase in μ and the decrease in N in the case of the N 2 gas atmosphere have been discussed in relation to the desorption of interstitial zinc, which is considered to act as a native donor in GZO [10] . The optical absorption spectra after annealing in air are displayed in Fig. 4 . Here the tail of the free carrier absorption was also subtracted. It can be seen that the intensity of the absorption band in the visible wavelength region decreased as T anneal increased. In the case of annealing in the N 2 atmosphere, we observed the same behavior. This suggests that a similar change in the GZO films occurred in both air and N 2 gas atmospheres. In addition, the variation in the optical absorption by post-deposition annealing was also similar to the dependence on the O 2 flow rate during deposition. In other words, the decrease in the intensity of the absorption band is concomitant with the decrease in carrier concentration. The absorption band in the visible wavelength range was prominent for the GZO films deposited under O 2 -deficient conditions, and the intensity of the absorption band weakened as the O 2 gas flow rate increased. The post-deposition annealing also decreased the intensity of the absorption band. These observations correlated with a change in the carrier concentration. In Fig. 5 , the integral intensities of the absorption bands for photon energies between 1.8 and 2.8 eV are plotted versus the carrier concentration for all the GZO films studied here. We can see that the absorption intensity shows a good correlation with the carrier concentration regardless of the annealing atmosphere or deposition conditions. The intensity monotonously decreased with the decrease of the carrier concentration and diminished at a carrier concentration of around 7 × 10 20 cm − 3 . The decrease in carrier concentration that occurred as the O 2 flow rate increased and due to post-deposition annealing, which was accompanied by a decrease in the intensity of the optical absorption band in the visible wavelength region, may be related to native donors in GZO films, that is, oxygen vacancies or interstitial Zn. If we assume that not only carriers from doped Ga donors but also carriers from native donors contribute to transport in the GZO films, such native donors could be reduced by additional oxygen during deposition or by post-deposition annealing. Then the optical absorption band would disappear with the reduced density of defects in the GZO films. In the case of post-deposition annealing, these phenomena occurred up to the critical temperatures observed in the electrical properties of the GZO films shown in Fig. 3 , and the decrease of defects in GZO films occurred at lower temperatures in the air atmosphere than in the N 2 atmosphere. Beyond the critical temperature, other drastic changes, such as the segregation of Ga at the grain boundary [10] , resulted in the serious degradation in the electrical properties of the GZO films. 4 Summary The optical absorption spectra of GZO films deposited by ion plating with DC arc discharge have been studied. The GZO films deposited under oxygen-deficient deposition conditions showed prominent absorption bands in the visible wavelength range. The intensity of the absorption band decreased as the O 2 flow rate increased during deposition. The post-deposition annealing also reduced the intensity of the visible absorption band. The change of absorption intensity showed a correlation with carrier concentrations greater than 7 × 10 20 cm − 3 . The intensity decreased with the decrease of the carrier concentration and diminished at a carrier concentration of around 7 × 10 20 cm − 3 . We suggested the possibility of a partial contribution from native donors to the total carrier concentration in GZO films. u3GgJxmn.title: Separation performance of sub-micron silica particles by electrical hydrocyclone
u3GgJxmn.abstract: The classification of a sub-micron silica suspension in an electrical hydrocyclone was studied. The classification of the sub-micron particles occurred at the applied electrostatic potentials greater than 40 V. Better classification performance was obtained with the increase of the applied electrostatic potentials. It was found that the particle cut size of the electrical hydrocyclone increased with the increase of the feed suspension waiting time, after particle dispersion by beads mill. The 50% cut size diameter decreased with the increase of the feed suspension concentration of up to 1.5 wt.%. Further increasing of the feed suspension concentration led to the increase of 50% cut size diameter.

j6580mdf.title: Nonpharmacological Management of Gout and Hyperuricemia: Hints for Better Lifestyle.
j6580mdf.abstract: We reviewed lifestyle factors that influence serum uric acid levels and risk of gout flare, and how to improve their deleterious effects. Since obesity increases uric acid and weight gain increases gout risk, weight reduction by daily exercise and limiting intake of excess calories is recommended. However, strenuous exercise, which causes adenine nucleotide degradation; starvation, which decreases uric acid excretion; and dehydration may raise the level of uric acid in serum and trigger gout. Increased intake of purine-rich foods, such as meat and seafood, raise the level of uric acid in serum and is associated with increased risk of gout, whereas dairy products, especially low-fat types, are associated with a lower risk of gout. Also, heavy alcohol drinking raises the uric acid level and increases the risk of gout through adenine nucleotide degradation and lactate production. Sweet fruits and soft drinks containing fructose should be moderated, since fructose may raise uric acid and increase gout risk through uric acid production and/or decreased excretion. On the other hand, the Mediterranean diet is recommended for gout patients, since it may also help prevent hyperuricemia. Furthermore, coffee and vitamin C supplementation could be considered as preventive measures, as those can lower serum uric acid levels as well as the risk of gout.

Fxwcjja9.title: Basic Principle and Image Analysis in the Diffusion Tensor Image.
Fxwcjja9.abstract: The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is established as the imaging technique that is essential to the imaging of the central nervous system disease. Above all, the diffusion weighted image (DWI) is known as the tool which can diagnose acute ischemic stroke with high accuracy in a short time. DTI, an applied form of DWI, was devised as a technique to image the structure of the brain white matter. In clinical sites, this technique is used for pathologic elucidation such as the intracerebral tissue injury or mental disorder. Additionally, diffusion tensor tractography (DTT), which is a technique to build three-dimensional structure of the neural fiber tracts, is used for grasping the relations between a brain tumor and the fibers tract. Therefore, these techniques may be useful imaging tools in the central nerve region.

ce70tqtR.title: Particle size control in the soap-free emulsion polymerization of styrene by an oil-soluble initiator with a weakly acidic water-soluble initiator
ce70tqtR.abstract: Abstract   The soap-free emulsion polymerization of styrene by an oil-soluble initiator, 2,2′-azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN), with a water-soluble initiator, 4,4′-azobis(4-cyanovaleric acid) (V-501), was conducted in water to control the size of the synthesized polymeric particles. The particle size and surface potential were monitored as concentration of V-501 used for the polymerization was varied. When the V-501 concentration was increased, the particle size increased because V-501 was a weak acid and reduced the surface potential, thereby promoting particle growth through coagulation. Additionally, V-501 can also function as a radical initiator, increasing the efficiency of the polymerization reaction and, thus, the number concentration of the particles.

EVMEbw9U.title: A Study of Frequency-Domain Signal Detection for Single- Carrier Transmission
EVMEbw9U.abstract: The bit error rate (BER) performance of single-carrier transmissions degrades due to a severe inter-symbol interference (ISI) in a frequency-selective fading channel. However, it can be significantly improved by using frequency-domain equalization. Recently, multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) spatial multiplexing is gaining much attention for achieving very high speed data communication. Various signal separation and detection schemes have been proposed for MIMO multiplexing. In this paper, it is pointed out that the frequency-domain received signal in single-carrier transmissions is similar to that of MIMO multiplexing, and the signal separation and detection schemes for MIMO multiplexing can be applied to the single-carrier detection. We evaluate, by computer simulation, the BER performance of single carrier transmissions using minimum mean square error (MMSE) detection and Vertical-bell laboratories layered space-time architecture (V-BLAST) detection. Keyword Single-carrier, frequency-domain signal detection, signal separation and detection for MIMO multiplexing

mWYLo5Wu.title: Succinate Dehydrogenase B Subunit–Negative Jugular Foramen Paraganglioma Manifesting Malignant Progression with Pseudohypoxia-Related Atypical Uptake of [18F]-Fluoro-2-Deoxy-d-Glucose: A Case Report
mWYLo5Wu.abstract: Background  Paragangliomas are generally benign, slow-growing tumors. However, approximately 10%–20% are malignant, characterized by distant metastasis. Recently, a germ line mutation in  succinate dehydrogenase B subunit  ( SDHB ) has been shown to be associated with malignant behavior in paraganglioma. Here we present a case of SDHB-negative malignant paraganglioma of the jugular foramen with a pseudohypoxic microenvironment and unique imaging features on [ 18 F]-fluoro-2-deoxy- d -glucose positron emission tomography ([ 18 F]-FDG PET), and discuss the significance of SDHB immunohistochemistry and the potential of [ 18 F]-FDG PET for clinical management.    Case Description  A 55-year-old woman was diagnosed with jugular foramen paraganglioma. Initial surgical resection was performed; however, follow-up [ 18 F]-FDG PET indicated multiple uptake regions throughout the body. Biopsies for multiple recurrent lesions revealed consistent pathological features, suggesting distant metastasis. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a lack of SDHB immunostaining in all specimens. Pseudohypoxic markers, including hypoxia-inducible factor-1α and downstream glycolysis enzymes, were strongly expressed. [ 18 F]-FDG PET demonstrated increased uptake in the lesions, and the patient died 3 years after initial metastasis.    Conclusion  In patients with head and neck paraganglioma without SDHB expression, close follow-up should be considered because of the risk for metastasis. In such cases, [ 18 F]-FDG PET might be useful for detecting metastasis due to atypical accumulation from pseudohypoxia-induced glycolysis.
